awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Wolbachia bacteria are maternally transmitted and infect the cells of nearly half of all insect species, and often hijack host reproduction to increase their spread. For example, many Wolbachia cause cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) that results in embryonic death when infected males fertilize uninfected eggs—infected eggs are rescued from this lethality, providing a relative fitness advantage to infected females. Several CI-causing Wolbachia that infect Drosophila also protect their host from viruses. In recent years, researchers have leveraged CI to transform mosquito populations with virus-blocking Wolbachia to successfully reduce the spread of Zika and dengue to humans on several continents. The strength of CI can vary greatly, from very weak to near complete embryonic death, but little is known about the genetic and cellular basis of this variation. Understanding this variation is crucial to explain the global Wolbachia pandemic in natural insect systems, and to improve the efficacy of Wolbachia biocontrol in transinfected-mosquito systems.
 
The Fellow’s PhD work revealed the genetic basis of CI, but the causes of pervasive CI-strength variation remain unknown. This postdoctoral research will determine the relative contributions of transcriptional and genetic diversity of CI-causing genes to variable CI strength. To achieve this goal, the Fellow will use a combination of genomics, transcriptomics, microscopy, and machine learning tools to rigorously dissect CI-strength variation across Drosophila. This project will identify the basis of CI strength diversity, enhance our understanding of the population genetics of this powerful drive mechanism, and inform vector control programs that leverage CI. During the fellowship period, the Fellow will also lead multiple broader impact initiatives including the development of workshops to teach Native American middle-school students about topics spanning biodiversity to molecular biology, and the introduction of a science club event for children in Missoula, Montana, to learn science through scientific games and activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Wolbachia are maternally transmitted endosymbiotic bacteria that are present in roughly half of all insect species. Many Wolbachia strains induce a phenomenon known as cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI),  where embryos fertilized by Wolbachia-bearing males die unless they too have Wolbachia. Understanding CI is crucial since CI partly determines Wolbachia’s unparalleled natural success and is currently deployed to control dengue by spreading pathogen-blocking Wolbachia through mosquito populations. This project's goals were to explore the variability in CI that ranges from complete to nearly imperceivable embryonic death, to determine CI's molecular causes, and to study Wolbachia-host ecological and evolutionary dynamics.

Initial findings revealed that the CI-inducing proteins CifA and CifB are nucleases that damage sperm DNA. Functional genetic tests determined that changes in Cif protein sequence directly affects CI strength and phenotypic outcomes. Further study explored how CI strength varies naturally, with a focus on within-system and cross-system variation. Data indicated that high levels of cifB transcription usually lead to strong CI. However, exceptions were found. For example, older male fruit flies showed weaker CI than younger males despite expressing more cifB transcripts. Likewise, one Wolbachia-Drosophila system caused strong CI with low cifB levels and another caused no CI despite high cifB levels. This indicates that cifB transcription levels, although important, are not the sole determinants of CI strength.

Furthermore, the project examined broader aspects of Wolbachia ecology and evolution. It investigated why Wolbachia prevalence varies along Australia's Eastern coast and found that temperature influences Wolbachia transmission from mother to offspring. This led to the discovery of a Wolbachia strain better suited to cold climates and the identification of a gene candidate responsible for cold acclimation. The project also revealed that Wolbachia can switch hosts on rapid evolutionary timescales, suggesting more frequent host interactions than previously thought.

Broad Impact

CI helps disseminate pathogen-blocking Wolbachia to high frequencies, curtailing the spread of dengue and other mosquito-borne viruses. However, the deployment of these strategies is not always successful, and there is a growing demand to expand to other arthropod disease vectors. This project's outcomes contribute to these challenges by enhancing our understanding of CI, identifying Wolbachia variants with potentially valuable characteristics, and providing insights toward Wolbachia’s transmission dynamics. The project provided mentorship to four early-career scientists, including two undergraduates and two post-baccalaureate trainees, of which three are women. One post-bacc trainee co-authored two publications related to the project. All participants are now pursuing careers in science or health, and three have enrolled in post-bacc programs. Beyond the lab, the project led to a comprehensive literature review on Wolbachia-host interactions, broadening scientific understanding of the topic. Educational outreach included engaging elementary and middle school students through Skype a Scientist and the Montana State Science Fair. Notably, one project publication led to a multi-year collaboration to develop a high school biology lab curriculum in Georgia. This collaboration has offered a diverse student cohort a platform for scientific inquiry, fostering new questions and avenues for research.


Last Modified: 11/19/2023
Modified by: John D Shropshire
